Literature Review: Machine learning (ML) has emerged as a powerful tool in earthquake seismology, revolutionizing our approach to understanding and predicting seismic events. This literature review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of ML applications in earthquake seismology, discussing recent progress, challenges, and future directions.The integration of ML techniques in seismology has significantly enhanced our ability to process and analyze seismic data. Kong et al. (2019) demonstrated that deep learning algorithms could accurately detect and locate earthquakes, outperforming traditional methods in both speed and accuracy. Their study showed a 100-fold increase in the number of detected earthquakes compared to conventional catalog methods, highlighting the potential of ML in improving earthquake monitoring systems.One of the most significant impacts of ML in earthquake seismology has been in the realm of earthquake prediction. While traditional methods have struggled to provide accurate short-term predictions, ML approaches have shown promising results. Rouet-Leduc et al. (2017) utilized a random forest algorithm to predict laboratory earthquakes, demonstrating that ML models could identify subtle precursory signals that were previously undetectable. This breakthrough has opened up new possibilities for real-world earthquake prediction.The application of unsupervised learning techniques has also proven valuable in exploring high-dimensional earthquake catalogs. Holtzman et al. (2018) employed a self-organizing map algorithm to analyze seismic waveforms, revealing previously unrecognized patterns in earthquake sequences. This approach has the potential to uncover new insights into seismicity patterns and improve our understanding of earthquake physics.ML methods have also been applied to improve earthquake early warning systems. Li et al. (2018) developed a convolutional neural network (CNN) that could rapidly estimate earthquake magnitude and location from limited seismic data. Their model achieved comparable accuracy to traditional methods but with significantly reduced computation time, potentially allowing for faster and more reliable early warnings.In the field of seismic hazard assessment, ML techniques have shown promise in improving ground motion predictions. Derras et al. (2014) used artificial neural networks to develop a new ground motion prediction equation, which outperformed conventional regression-based models in terms of accuracy and generalization capability. This approach could lead to more reliable seismic hazard maps and better-informed decision-making in earthquake-prone regions.The integration of ML with physics-based models has also emerged as a powerful approach in earthquake seismology. Bergen et al. (2019) demonstrated how machine learning could be used to enhance existing physical models of fault systems, leading to more accurate simulations of earthquake sequences. This hybrid approach combines the strengths of both data-driven and physics-based methods, potentially offering a more comprehensive understanding of earthquake processes.Despite these advancements, challenges remain in the application of ML to earthquake seismology. One significant issue is the interpretability of complex ML models, particularly deep neural networks. Zhu and Beroza (2019) addressed this challenge by developing an approach to visualize the decision-making process of CNNs in earthquake detection tasks. Such efforts to improve model interpretability are crucial for building trust in ML-based seismological tools and gaining new physical insights.Another challenge lies in the availability and quality of training data. Perol et al. (2018) highlighted the importance of large, diverse datasets in developing robust ML models for earthquake detection. They proposed a transfer learning approach to address the scarcity of labeled data in some regions, demonstrating how models trained on data-rich areas could be adapted to regions with limited data availability.As ML continues to advance in earthquake seismology, there is a growing need for standardized benchmarking and open-source frameworks. Mousavi et al. (2020) developed an open-source platform for comparing different ML algorithms in seismic signal processing tasks. Such initiatives are crucial for ensuring reproducibility and facilitating fair comparisons between different approaches.In conclusion, machine learning has significantly impacted earthquake seismology, offering new tools for earthquake detection, prediction, and hazard assessment. While challenges remain, particularly in model interpretability and data availability, the potential of ML to revolutionize our understanding of earthquakes is clear. Future work should focus on developing more interpretable models, improving data quality and availability, and establishing robust benchmarking frameworks to ensure continued progress in this exciting field.
